tests/unit/test_connection.py.message:
There isn't a bug, but the issue is that you were using orderedRelease, which releases builds one at a time after each has completed, but you have configured the -merge job to pause, which means it can't complete until all the children are done.

The solution, to disable hold_jobs_in_build is reasonable.

Another solution would be to release the jobs by name in order, but as you pointed out, we don't really need information from the other jobs, so we don't really care what order they run in.  We only require that the first build id be the merge job.

I recommend you rephrase the comment to simply indicate that we don't care about the order the child jobs run in, only that project-merge is first, and using orderedRelease with paused jobs is complex, so we have disabled the hold.
Thanks for the explanation. This makes sense. I've rephrased the comment.
With the above in mind, we don't actually need lines 317 and 318 here.

I've noticed a lot of places the this style for doing ternary operations,

 {{ 'primary_text_value' if (some_condition == false) else 'alternate_text_value' }}

and while foreign to me they seem to work just fine. But I got a bit curious when I came across this particular one. And it doesn't seem to work as intended, here's a quick test-case;

 ---
 - name: test
   hosts: localhost
   vars:
     kolla_container_engine: docker
     #docker_runtime_directory: /test
   tasks:
     - debug:
         msg: "Path: {{ docker_runtime_directory or '/var/lib/docker' if 
 kolla_container_engine=='docker' else '/var/lib/containers/storage' }}"

 {{ (kolla_container_engine == 'docker') | ternary(docker_runtime_directory | default('/var/lib/docker'), '/var/lib/containers/storage') }}

Reading the bug description, the problem should be in [1][2]. If [2] is returning False (thus [1] is setting accept_ra=1), this is because the IPv6 address is in the keepalived config in case of being backup node. Is that the case that is happening in your environment?

If not, [1] should be setting accept_ra=0.

[1]https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/a9730576b1d86e995ce4cf0db165a9830e2ba800/neutron/agent/l3/ha_router.py#L328
[2]https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/a9730576b1d86e995ce4cf0db165a9830e2ba800/neutron/agent/l3/ha_router.py#L311

Okay. I just had a second look at my patch and you are right. The patch as is "only" fixes accept_ra on a router failover but after an agent restart the accept_ra value is getting set to wrong value again on backup routers.

So we need a kind of refresh function to get the right value on a failover and also fix the `_disable_ipv6_addressing_on_interface`.

At the moment I am thinking about disabling accept_ra always in `_disable_ipv6_addressing_on_interface` as all routers start as backup and one of them will trigger the refresh function when it gets promoted to primary.

Hi Rodolfo,
yes I think that their might be work todo in those function aswell.
The problem I had when "fixing" those functions was that the correct state only got applied when I restart the neutron-l3-agent. 
So it seems that on a new router `_disable_ipv6_addressing_on_interface` is always getting executed as being standby and is also not getting executed on a router failover.

Thats the reason I added the `refresh_accept_ra` function, this handles all cases in my test environment. 
On a fresh router the value gets applied when the first router switches to primary as well as when a failover occurs.
I am not sure if thats the best solution to this problem.

.zuul.yaml.message:
i don't think we should do this, is it needed?

It seems like we're mostly commited to just keeping all of our testenv's working with whatever latest tox we get, why would we want THIS job to force us to maintain a configuraiton that's compatible with an older version of tox?

If you want to try to get it to work, you're welcome to -- the tricks I used for other test envs didn't work here; not sure why.

Seems reasonable to expect that if we're going to test with super-old versions of all our deps, we ought to include a super-old version of tox, too -- so I guess I'd flip it and say, why '<4' and not '==3.18.0' (or previously, '==2.3.2')?

As far as maintaining a config that's compatible with older versions of tox -- I'm pretty sure we'd want to do that *anyway*. And not out of the goodness of our hearts for packagers that currently have tox 3.x CI systems or something -- but because tox 4 dropped support for py27 and py36, both of which we want to test.

Longer term, I'd seriously consider getting rid of the lower-constraints job entirely:

- As demonstrated, it's hard to make sure we're actually accomplishing what we set out to do
- It's hard to tell what value we're actually getting out of it
- Most of the rest of OpenStack has already gotten rid of it *anyway*

Seems to warrant a separate discussion, though, rather than axe it because our gate is broken.

ProblemDetails is saved with an error String passed as argument in _send_lcm_op_occ_notification function.
This action is the same for the Infra Driver as well as the Mgmt Driver.
If we use MgmtDriverException, how do we pass the data to _send_lcm_op_occ_notification?

Any error is passed to the _send_lcm_op_occ_notification function as it is.
Then, type of the error is checked in the function.
If the type is not ProblemDetails, the error is stored as same as current implementation.
So we need to implement such a process in the _send_lcm_op_occ_notification function.

devstack/plugin.sh.message:
I don't see how be_name is being set anywhere.  I think what you need here is something like:

  local be_name="${1:-nfs}"
  
which will give you backward-compatible behavior (if configure_cinder_nfs is called with an argument, it's used; if it's called without an argument, 'nfs' is used).

be_name is set in devstack[1] which is the name of backend and is used in all places where a backend name needs to be defined (cinder.conf, volume type etc).
When we set nfs:nfsdriver-1 in local.conf then nfs is the "be_type" and nfsdriver-1 is the "be_name" which needs to be used here for cinder.conf (instead of hardcoded nfs).
Since devstack-plugin-nfs is always used along with devstack, be_name will always be set.
I would agree with your approach but currently configure_cinder_nfs is not called with any argument[2] and not even sure if devstack passes that while calling the plugin so this seems to be the only possible approach.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/devstack/blob/1054f12bdac0208e73f22e16fe77edb87886722d/lib/cinder#L161

[2] https://github.com/openstack/devstack-plugin-nfs/blob/dd12367f90fc86d42bfebe8a0ebb694dc0308810/devstack/plugin.sh#L102

OK, so this function confuses me:

https://github.com/openstack/devstack/blob/448036a6ad382cebcf9df15f717e259479be4965/lib/cinder_backends/nfs#L31

... because that one clearly needs a parameter passed in (the local var overrides any current be_name env var).

My overall objection is that usually in devstack, global vars are ALL_CAPS and locals are lowercase (though it's not enforced).  So it's not at all obvious where this be_name is being set and whether it's local to the file or what.

I won't block this patch, but there seems to be a code smell here.

Yes, but not necessarily to the same attributes. We propose that Prometheus Plugin's event requests related to PM/FM IFs are the same design.

> "receiver" and "status" are unnecessary and "receiver_type" and "function_type" are necessary...
"receiver" attribute is provided by External Monitoring tools and not used in the Tacker process. "status" attribute is also unnecessary because the same information included in "labels.status", and it shows a status of each alert that is used in the Tacker process too.

Pattern A. vnfcInstanceId is included in the request.
* Pattern A-1. all = False is included in the request or all is not included in the request. Only specified VNFC instances are healed.
* Pattern A-2. all = True are included in the request. Specified VNFC instances and storage resources are healed.

Why introduce this option when `extend_attached_volume` already exists and its purpose is clear: "Also, not all volume or compute backends support this operation." This echos the issue in your commit message: "However, not every volume backend supports this operation."

Perhaps consider updating the devstack condition around this instead: http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack-dev/devstack/tree/lib/tempest#n455

If the backend does not support online extend 2 situations can happen:

 - driver is aware and reports 'online_extend=False'. In this case the operation
   will fail with 'NoValidHostFound', the negative test will PASS, positive FAIL.

 - driver is not aware and does not report online_extend (scheduler will
  proceed with creation). In this case, the driver can extend the volume, but
  nothing will actually happen on Nova side. Or, the driver might trhow and error
  leaving the volume in error state, the negative test will FAIL, positive can
  FAIL or PASS depending on backend.

Thanks Erlon. It seems unpredictable behaviour from driver when online extend is not supported. there can be 2-3 cases in this situation and depends on driver. ANd we will not be able to guarantee that what behaviour this negative test should verify.

so i do not think we should test such negative case with unpredictable behaviour. Testing the positive case with exiting test and existing config options makes much more sense.

Got your point that we need this variable for negative tests where this feature is not supported and tests can verify that size is unchanged. 

From this, i understood that if extended_volume is not present and it is requested then, cinder will not error and keep the original size. Will user get same success code as they get then it is success ? if so then, is it not confusing or false success ? 

If cinder behaviour is success in above case then, we can go with below approach
- Check the variable behaviour (whether size is changed or not) based on existing 'extend_attached_volume' config option instead of skipping the tests itself. 
- Run the tests always as no side effect if this test run against env where this feature is not supported. 

If Cinder is error or there is other side effect (on nova etc) then,
- we just check the positive case, we do not need to check error case of this feature is not available which is obvious and can be covered on cinder unit test itself.

This is tricky, so, this new option says to tempest whether the backend being tested supports online_extend or not.

So, with this patch, we have now 2 tests for online_extend. One tests the behavior of backends that supports online_extend, the other tests the behaviour of backends that does not support it.

The existent extend_attached_volume will say whether to run those tests or not.

honestly speaking, i don't understand the rationale of CONF.network_feature_enabled.port_security.
as you +2'ed the change [1], you know it better than i do. :-)

[1] I1efd5c838aa0d73cc6e8864e3041eea25850198d
Shouldn't this be a "or" instead of an "and" ?

yea we have 2 contradicted config options here and one really break some deployment. 

I agree with Andrea that we cannot change the default value of port_security to True which breaks people.

So 'and' condition looks a much better solution here which solve bug#1638487 and also honor the port_security config options also.

Below can be possible deployment:
 
1. port_security=True, api_extensions='all' (or it include port-security extension).
- old behavior: create net with 'port_security_enabled', 
- new behavior: same

2. port_security=false, api_extensions='all' (or it include port-security extension).
- old behavior: create net without 'port_security_enabled', 
- new behavior: same

3. port_security=True, api_extensions=[it does not include port-security extension].
- old behavior: create net with 'port_security_enabled', 
- new behavior: changed

4. port_security=false, api_extensions=[it does not include port-security extension].
- old behavior: create net without 'port_security_enabled', 
- new behavior: same

case 3rd is what this bug is about where actual port-security extension not available but port_security option was true.

making it 'or' condition makes behavior change for 2nd.

So 3rd case leads to failure where it add 'port_security_enabled' in API request which is failed by neutron.
and 2nd is the where it does not include the extra attribute in request so no failure from neutron(but yea it can leads to other test behavior change).

But we have to take one decision. I think we go with 'and' condition with deprecation of port_security config option and with well documented about this behavior change and recommend to use api_extensions.

This is kind of an impossible situation :S

Since config is a stable interface, we need to honour the current behaviour.

Right now we have an inconsistent default, where port-security is False by default, but the list of api_extensions == all by default. The current logic behaves so that port-security overrides api_extensions, so we need to respect that until the deprecation cycle is over.

However, saying that port-security is deprecated means that we encourage our users to use the list in api_extensions only. But if they do so, the default value (False) of port-security will cause the test to be skipped.

But we cannot change the default to "True" either because that would change the default behaviour in case nothing is changed in the configuration, so network scenario tests would suddenly start using port_security.

So the only way out I see is via documentation i.e. tell this option is deprecated, but in case you want to enable port_security please set it to true, which is really ugly. Does anyone has a better idea?
my understanding is that for older branches it needs to be disabled in case api_extensions=all and port_security=false.

the introduction of the new port_security option, with the associated devstack change, changed the behaviour for the certain configuration and broke compatibility.  i'm not sure why we can't change it again.

yea, there is no best solution here and we have to go with better one.

As discussed on IRC we can go with following approach.

As current change(L703) will change behavior of 3rd case only, we can raise InvalidConfiguration exception in that case (where port_security=True, api_extensions=[it does not include port-security extension]) with proper message saying that

"There are two conflict config options in tempest.conf: network_feature_enabled[port_security]=%s, network_feature_enabled[api_extensions]=%s.  CONF.network_feature_enabled.port_security has been deprecated and will be removed in future. Configure the api_extensions correctly to include the 'port-security' extension as per your cloud configuration. 

So if anyone changed the default value of 'port_security' and not configured the 'api_extensions' with 'port-security' extension will fail.

I believe it should be OR here. Yes, it may break some setups with wrong configuration (where they specify port-security in api_extensions - or all - but don't want to execute the tests), but that makes sense to enable the tests for those that correctly configure tempest with just api_extensions.

neutron/common/ovn/extensions.py.message:
this isn't good way to do that because OVN don't really supports dhcp agent scheduler and You cannot e.g. schedule network to be hosted on the DHCP agent.
Maybe instead we should introduce something like "forced api extensions" which can be scheduled by mech drivers and if extension would be in that forced list it would be enabled even if other drivers wouldn't support it. Wdyt?

Thanks for adding Rodolfo. That's correct, we can use ML2/OVN with Neutron DHCP for certain cases. The one we usually have is baremetal, since OVN built-server was lacking iPXE chainloading support (still lacks it for IPv6) we need to also deploy Neutron DHCP agent for those cases.

This patch adds support for it for example: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/840287
Actually we do support using DHCP agents along with OVN mech driver for, for example, external SRIOV ports. I think we can add this extension here. Let me add Lucas to this review.
